item.title: [pi] Updated different experience modes easy,medium,hard and extreme
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

So let me point out some of the flaws here.

  1. You shouldn’t name the boolean “finishedTutorial”. They’re not finishing a tutorial. They’re selecting a exp mode. Giving variables names related to what they do helps when you go back into the code to make edits. Or it helps when others are making edits to your code.
  2. There is no need to save 6 booleans for each exp mode. You should use an integer, or an Enum. Using multiple booleans like this is just going to result in clunky code all the way around.
  3. You should not be changing the values of static variables the way you are here:
Find these:

Add under:

if (c.dialogueAction == 850) { Config.MELEE_EXP_RATE = 5000; Config.RANGE_EXP_RATE = 5000; Config.MAGIC_EXP_RATE = 5000; c.easyMode = true; c.finishedTut = true; c.getPA().removeAllWindows(); }

Find:

Add Under:

if (c.dialogueAction == 850) { Config.MELEE_EXP_RATE = 500; Config.RANGE_EXP_RATE = 500; Config.MAGIC_EXP_RATE = 500; c.mediumMode = true; c.finishedTut = true; c.getPA().removeAllWindows(); }

Find:

Add Under:

if (c.dialogueAction == 850) { Config.MELEE_EXP_RATE = 50; Config.RANGE_EXP_RATE = 50; Config.MAGIC_EXP_RATE = 50; c.hardMode = true; c.finishedTut = true; c.getPA().removeAllWindows(); }

Find:

Under add:

if (c.dialogueAction == 850) { Config.MELEE_EXP_RATE = 10; Config.RANGE_EXP_RATE = 10; Config.MAGIC_EXP_RATE = 10; c.extremeMode = true; c.finishedTut = true; c.getPA().removeAllWindows(); }

That will change the exp modifiers for the entire server not just a single person.

  1. You assume people have code that did not come in the original PI server:
Find this

Add under:

dialoguehandler.java


5) Again, you are accessing variables in a static way when you should be accessing them in a non-static way.
Find Somthing Like this

Add this Above:

public static int meleeExp() { if (Player.easyMode) { } else if (Player.mediumMode) { } else if (Player.hardMode) { } else if (Player.extremeMode) { } return Config.MELEE_EXP_RATE; } public static int rangeExp() { if (Player.easyMode) { } else if (Player.mediumMode) { } else if (Player.hardMode) { } else if (Player.extremeMode) { } return Config.RANGE_EXP_RATE; } public static int magicExp() { if (Player.easyMode) { } else if (Player.mediumMode) { } else if (Player.hardMode) { } else if (Player.extremeMode) { } return Config.MAGIC_EXP_RATE; }


6) Why the hell are you setting the finishedTut variable to false?:

[quote=“haviland4, post:1, topic:551473”]Than in Client.java find this

under PlayerSave.saveGame(this);

add Player.finishedTut = false;[/quote]
Again: Stop accessing variables that should not be static in a static way

Edit: I just noticed this:

[code]public static int meleeExp() { if (Player.easyMode) { } else if (Player.mediumMode) { } else if (Player.hardMode) { } else if (Player.extremeMode) { } return Config.MELEE_EXP_RATE; } public static int rangeExp() { if (Player.easyMode) { } else if (Player.mediumMode) { } else if (Player.hardMode) { } else if (Player.extremeMode) { } return Config.RANGE_EXP_RATE; } public static int magicExp() { if (Player.easyMode) { } else if (Player.mediumMode) { } else if (Player.hardMode) { } else if (Player.extremeMode) { } return Config.MAGIC_EXP_RATE; }[/code]
There is no reason for the else if statements if they're empty.

Lastly: This is not a tutorial. You explain code in a tutorial. All you did is throw it in people’s face and told them to copy pasta.
